perturbation.explanation: Moving the Injunctive Relief clause to the 'Delay' section buries a critical remedy within a less relevant clause, potentially obscuring its importance and impact on enforcement. The legal right to injunctive relief and associated fee recovery are best highlighted in a section dedicated to remedies and consequences of breach of contract, not in a clause discussing delays.
perturbation.law_explanation: FRCP 65 outlines the requirements and procedures for obtaining a preliminary injunction and temporary restraining order. By obscuring the Injunctive Relief clause within a section about 'Delay', the contract makes it more difficult for a party to quickly and easily understand its rights and the process for seeking injunctive relief, potentially hindering their ability to meet the procedural requirements outlined in FRCP 65.

Injunctions and Restraining Orders (a) Preliminary Injunction. (1) Notice. The court may issue a preliminary injunction only on notice to the adverse party. (2) Consolidating the Hearing with the Trial on the Merits. Before or after beginning the hearing on a motion for a preliminary injunction, the court may advance the trial on the merits and consolidate it with the hearing. Even when consolidation is not ordered, evidence that is received on the motion and that would be admissible at trial becomes part of the trial record and need not be repeated at trial. But the court must preserve any party's right to a jury trial. (b) Temporary Restraining Order. (1) Issuing Without Notice. The court may issue a temporary restraining order without written or oral notice to the adverse party or its attorney only if: (A) specific facts in an affidavit or a verified complaint clearly show that immediate and irreparable injury, loss, or damage will result to the movant before the adverse party can be heard in opposition; and (B) the movant's attorney certifies in writing any efforts made to give notice and the reasons why it should not be required. (2) Contents; Expiration. Every temporary restraining order issued without notice must state the date and hour it was issued; describe the injury and state why it is irreparable; state why the order was issued without notice; and be promptly filed in the clerk's office and entered in the record. The order expires at the time after entry—not to exceed 14 days—that the court sets, unless before that time the court, for good cause, extends it for a like period or the adverse party consents to a longer extension. perturbation.original_text: 1. Confidential Information. Member shall not, during the term of the Franchise Agreement or thereafter, communicate, divulge or use, for any purpose other than the operation of the Franchised Business, any confidential information, knowledge, trade secrets or know-how which may be communicated to Member or which Member may learn by virtue of Member's relationship with Franchisee. All information, knowledge and know-how relating to Franchisor, its business plans, Franchised Businesses, or the System ("Confidential Information") is deemed confidential, except for information that Member can demonstrate came to Member's attention by lawful means prior to disclosure to Member; or which, at the time of the disclosure to Member, had become a part of the public domain.

perturbation.explanation: Relocating the definition of 'Confidential Information' to the section addressing 'Delay' disrupts the logical flow and understanding of the contract. The scope and restrictions surrounding confidential information are no longer readily apparent, making it difficult to ascertain the obligations regarding trade secrets. Placing it under Delay obscures its essential context.
perturbation.law_explanation: UTSA § 1(4) defines what constitutes a trade secret. By moving the clause that defines 'Confidential Information' to the 'Delay' section, a court might question whether the definition was properly disclosed and agreed upon, potentially weakening the claim that the information qualifies as a trade secret under UTSA. The law requires reasonable efforts to maintain secrecy; hiding the definition hinders the ability to demonstrate such efforts.

perturbation.original_text: 4. Severability. All agreements and covenants contained herein are severable. If any of them, or any part or parts of them, shall be held invalid by any court of competent jurisdiction for any reason, then the Member agrees that the court shall have the authority to reform and modify that provision in order that the restriction shall be the maximum necessary to protect Franchisor's and/or Franchisee's legitimate business needs as permitted by applicable law and public policy. In so doing, the Member agrees that the court shall impose the provision with retroactive effect as close as possible to the provision held to be invalid.
perturbation.changed_text: 6. Third-Party Beneficiary. Member hereby acknowledges and agrees that Franchisor is an intended third-party beneficiary of this Agreement with the right to enforce it, independently or jointly with Franchisee. 4. Severability. All agreements and covenants contained herein are severable. If any of them, or any part or parts of them, shall be held invalid by any court of competent jurisdiction for any reason, then the Member agrees that the court shall have the authority to reform and modify that provision in order that the restriction shall be the maximum necessary to protect Franchisor's and/or Franchisee's legitimate business needs as permitted by applicable law and public policy. In so doing, the Member agrees that the court shall impose the provision with retroactive effect as close as possible to the provision held to be invalid.
perturbation.explanation: Shifting the severability clause to the end of the document, directly after the third-party beneficiary clause reduces the immediate visibility and prominence of this key provision. It is now outside the core operating terms and obligations, leading to a less clear understanding of how the agreement's components are protected and how to determine the validity of its operating terms.
perturbation.law_explanation: Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 184 outlines the principle of severability, which addresses the enforceability of a contract when a portion of it is deemed invalid. By placing the severability clause after the 'Third-Party Beneficiary' section, it may imply a potential conflict or limit to that severability, even though no such explicit limitation is given. It suggests it's not of paramount importance. This misplaced emphasis makes it harder to clearly establish the intent to preserve the contract's validity to the greatest extent possible, contradicting the principle that a contract should be interpreted in a way that renders it valid and enforceable.
